description: This is a junior level laboratory course. The course teaches the principles of design and measurement systems including basic electromechanical systems. It follows MEAM 302 and MEAM 321 including experiments in fluid mechanics, and vibration in the design of mechanical systems.
name: LECTURE

values.comments:
This is a junior level laboratory course. The course teaches the principles of design and measurement systems including basic electromechanical systems. It follows MEAM 302 and MEAM 321 including experiments in fluid mechanics, and vibration in the design of mechanical systems.

Students generally found the course to be frustrating and time-consuming. Many complained that the labs were extremely disorganized. Some stated that there were often not enough equipment and materials, and lab instructions were often changed, giving students “a perverse incentive to start their projects at the last minute.” Some students also felt that the quizzes were useless and proposed having homework corresponding to the labs instead. 

Professor Yim was described by many as a helpful and approachable instructor. Students generally felt that it was convenient that the professor could be reached on gchat. However, many doubted that he had worked through the labs before they were assigned. Many students were unsatisfied with Professor Yim’s explanation that the lack of lab materials was to simulate real world engineering problems. 

The workload for this course was regarded by most students as being extremely heavy. Some students reported putting in more than 20 hours a week to finish assignments. According to many, the grading curve was harsh and did not reflect the amount of time and effort spent. Because of the difficulty and time required, this course is only recommended for majors.

This course studies pressure, density, velocity, forces and introduces aerodynamics and aircraft performance. 

Students generally enjoyed the class and found it to be fun. Most felt that the course was their “favorite MEAM course.” One student said it was the only class he “looked forward to attending all semester” and another was “sad when the class ended.” Students liked the use of real data and application of problems, although some commented that the course could have gone into greater depth in some topics.

While most students found the material to be difficult, they praised Professor Kothmann’s ability to make it accessible and the professor’s commitment to helping students understand. Students generally described Professor Kothmann as “passionate,” “knowledgeable,” and “helpful.”

Despite it being a 200-level MEAM course, interested non-MEAM-engineers and non-engineers still found the course to be understandable and enjoyable largely due to Professor Kothmann’s teaching style.
